channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-5610] ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes
item.description:
ServerPropertiesTest showed the below output when running. The ping retries and the test passes.
I am not sure if in fact a Connection reset is a valid response if the server is not fully up and the test is just being too verbose or if it is real problem that we get this Error.

item.summary: ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The reason the stack trace prints is that in NetworkServerTestSetup.pingForServerUp() we have this code:

if ( !vetPing( e ) )
{
e.printStackTrace( System.out );

Where vetPing does:
// return false if ping returns an error other than "server not up yet"
private static boolean vetPing( Throwable t )
{
if ( !t.getClass().getName().equals( "java.lang.Exception" ) )

{ return false; }

return ( t.getMessage().startsWith( "DRDA_NoIO.S:" ) );
}

I think perhaps the network server code needs to be wrapping java.net.SocketException and is not for some reason.

The reason the stack trace prints is that in NetworkServerTestSetup.pingForServerUp() we have this code:

if ( !vetPing( e ) )
{
e.printStackTrace( System.out );

Where vetPing does:
// return false if ping returns an error other than "server not up yet"
private static boolean vetPing( Throwable t )
{
if ( !t.getClass().getName().equals( "java.lang.Exception" ) )

{ return false; }

return ( t.getMessage().startsWith( "DRDA_NoIO.S:" ) );
}

I think perhaps the network server code needs to be wrapping java.net.SocketException and is not for some reason.

I think this is actually a NetworkServer bug pingWithNoOpen should catch the IO exception and wrap it and then it would pass vetPing. I am not sure the best way to test.

There are a couple of prints to System.out on errors in pingForServerUp. I think maybe these should be removed and just throw the error so test runs that only check for failures and not stack traces in the run output will catch unexpected failures.
I tend to think that should be a separate checkin once tests settle down, so we don't introduce more volatility. I will file a separate issue for that.
Here is a patch for this issue. I am
Triage for 10.9

I am finally returning to this issue. Here is a patch derby-5610_trunkdiff.txt that I think will wrap the Socket exception with a localized DRDA Exception and then the test should get the exception it expect and not print to stdout.

I am not sure how to test the patch. I also seem to recall being concerned about this fix at one point but cannot remember why. I will work on seeing if I can force the SocketException with the patch to see what the behavior is.

To force a SocketException, I changed pingWithNoOpen to have

private static int pingtry = 0;
private void pingWithNoOpen() throws Exception
{
....
send();
readResult();
if (pingtry == 0)

{ pingtry++; throw new java.net.SocketException("SocketException"); }

Without the patch I see the exception print, With the patch I do not, so I think I will go ahead and commit the patch unless anyone sees any issues.

URL: http://svn.apache.org/r1484507
Log:
DERBY-5610 ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes

Merged to 10.10 branch. Don't plan to go back further at this time.

Sending java\drda\org\apache\derby\impl\drda\NetworkServerControlImpl.java
Transmitting file data .
Committed revision 1485264.
Will work on backporting this to 10.9 and 10.8

Commit 1504520 from Mamta A. Satoor in branch 'code/branches/10'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1504520 ]

DERBY-5610(ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes)

Backporting to 10.9. Fix contributed by Kathey

Commit 1504760 from Mamta A. Satoor in branch 'code/branches/10'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1504760 ]

DERBY-5610(ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes)

Backporting to 10.8. Fix contributed by Kathey

I got another report of this issue so reopening the bug. I still have not been able to reproduce the actual issue but find that if I force a java.net.SocketException in NetworkServerControlImpl.fillReplyBuffer()
try

{ replyBufferCount = clientIs.read(replyBuffer); throw new java.net.SocketException(); }

that the exception still prints to the console when I use the NetworkServerControl.ping() API. I think with the API we should not see the exception print to the console it should just be thrown back to the user. Thanks to Myrna for helping me find this.

So I think the problem comes down to consoleExceptionPrintTrace which has
public void consoleExceptionPrintTrace(Throwable e)
{
consoleMessage(e.getMessage(), true);
PrintWriter lw = logWriter;
if (lw != null)
{
synchronized (lw)

{ e.printStackTrace(lw); }

}
else

{ e.printStackTrace(); <== Problem with API ping printing stack trace }

....

For the API calls no logwriter is set so it goes to the e.printStackTrace(). I am wondering what is the case where this would be necessary or desirable.
Attaching a patch that puts the e.printStackTrace() in a if (debugOutput) block. I am hesitant to remove it completely.
Resolved in trunk with revision 1526172, in 10.10 with revision 1526486.

I had missed that the second commit was not backported to 10.9 & 10.8.
I will do that.

Commit 1569125 from Myrna van Lunteren in branch 'code/branches/10.9'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1569125 ]

DERBY-5610; ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes
backport of revision 1526486 from trunk.

Commit 1569137 from Myrna van Lunteren in branch 'code/branches/10.8'

DERBY-5610; ServerPropertiesTest prints .java.net.SocketException: Connection reset to console but test passes
